If we consider the exact mathematical definition of a breakpoint, it occurs where the definition changes. The slope changes from $20.85$ to $-25.58$. Thus, $x = -6.56$ is a breakpoint.

**Breakpoint at $x = 1.26$:**
For the second piece, as $x$ approaches $1.26$ from the left (i.e., $x \leq 1.26$), the function value is $f(x) = -25.58 x - 67.81$.
The limit from the left is $\lim_{x \to 1.26^-} (-25.58 x - 67.81) = -25.58(1.26) - 67.81 = -32.2308 - 67.81 = -100.0408$.
At $x = 1.26$, the second piece gives $f(1.26) = -25.58(1.26) - 67.81 = -100.0408$.

For the third piece, as $x$ approaches $1.26$ from the right (i.e., $x > 1.26$), the function value is $f(x) = 31.99 x - 140.27$.

The function value at $x = 1.26$ according to the third piece's interval definition is $f(1.26) = 31.99(1.26) - 140.27 = -99.9626$.

Again, there is a slight difference between the left and right limits at $x = 1.26$ due to rounding. The slope changes from $-25.58$ to $31.99$. Thus, $x = 1.26$ is a breakpoint.

**Breakpoint at $x = 7.5$:**

At $x = 7.5$, the third piece gives $f(7.5) = 31.99(7.5) - 140.27 = 99.655$.

For the fourth piece, as $x$ approaches $7.5$ from the right (i.e., $x > 7.5$), the function value is $f(x) = 374.62 - 36.62 x$.
